The TGA is the Therapeutic Goods Administration in Australia.

clusters.title: Experience: I gave birth to the world’s first IVF boy
clusters.neutral_headline: Experience: I gave birth to the world’s first IVF boy: My husband and I were unable to have children, and then we heard about a new experimental techniqueI was 26 when my gynaecologist told me that my fallopian tubes were blocked and there would be no way I could get pregnant. I was devastated. I had always wanted children. It was 1972; I was living in Bishopbriggs, near Glasgow, and working as a college lecturer. IVF didn’t exist, and when my husband and I put our names down to adopt a baby, we were told we had very little chance because few babies were available to adopt at the time. Meanwhile, my gynaecologist tried to open my fallopian tubes. It didn’t work.I refused to accept that I had no options. I read every article I could about fertility treatment. After three years, I heard about a medical breakthrough by gynaecologist Patrick Steptoe and physiologist Robert Edwards. It was described as very experimental and new. Continue reading

She researched fertility treatments for three years.
She learned of a breakthrough by Steptoe and Edwards.
The technique was described as experimental and new.

clusters.title: Rising racism blamed for collapse in number of foreign nurses coming to UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Rising racism blamed for collapse in number of foreign nurses coming to UK: Number of overseas nurses and midwives registered between April and September was half that of a year agoThe number of overseas nurses and midwives coming to the UK is collapsing, figures reveal, with rising racism and changes to immigration rules blamed for the fall.Between April and September, 6,321 nurses and midwives from abroad joined the register of those licensed to practice in the UK, compared with 12,534 who did so in the same period in 2024. Continue reading

Continue reading...

ai_summary: The number of overseas nurses joining the UK register is falling.
Rising racism and immigration rule changes are blamed.
6,321 nurses and midwives joined between April and September.
This is less than half the number from the previous year.
The data compares figures from April to September 2024.

clusters.title: GPs failing older people living with frailty, National Audit Office finds
clusters.neutral_headline: GPs failing older people living with frailty, National Audit Office finds

items.title: GPs failing older people living with frailty, National Audit Office finds
items.standfirst: Of patients diagnosed with condition in 2024/25, only 18% were assessed for fall risk and just 16% had a medical reviewGPs are failing to provide adequate support for people living with frailty, an independent watchdog has found.Frailty is a syndrome related to ageing and in which body systems gradually lose their in-built reserves. Symptoms include exhaustion and people living with frailty are more likely to be housebound. Continue reading...
items.content: Of patients diagnosed with condition in 2024/25, only 18% were assessed for fall risk and just 16% had a medical reviewGPs are failing to provide adequate support for people living with frailty, an independent watchdog has found.Frailty is a syndrome related to ageing and in which body systems gradually lose their in-built reserves. Symptoms include exhaustion and people living with frailty are more likely to be housebound. Continue reading...

ai_summary: GPs are failing to provide adequate support for frailty.
Only 18% of patients were assessed for fall risk.
Just 16% had a medical review in 2024/25.
Frailty is linked to aging and loss of body reserves.
Symptoms include exhaustion and potential housebound status.

clusters.title: CDC advisers delay vote on restricting infant hepatitis B vaccinations in tense meeting
clusters.neutral_headline: CDC advisers delay vote on restricting infant hepatitis B vaccinations in tense meeting: From 1990 to 2019, reported cases of acute hepatitis B among kids declined by 99% due to infant immunizationAfter a contentious meeting, vaccine advisers for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) voted on Thursday to delay a vote on restricting hepatitis B vaccination for infants until Friday.The meeting of the advisory committee on immunization practices (ACIP) turned confrontational at times before one member introduced a motion to delay the vote, which passed by six to three, to give advisers time to examine the wording before taking a vote. Continue reading

Reported hepatitis B cases declined by 99% due to immunization.

clusters.title: I realise now that my view on mental health overdiagnosis was divisive. We all need better evidence | Wes Streeting
clusters.neutral_headline: I realise now that my view on mental health overdiagnosis was divisive. We all need better evidence | Wes Streeting: The surge in mental ill health is hugely distressing. That’s why I’ve commissioned a review to find out what’s driving itEarlier this year, I appeared on the BBC and was asked a question by Laura Kuenssberg that I hadn’t anticipated: did I believe there’s a problem with mental health overdiagnosis?I gave a simple answer, that yes, I did think there was overdiagnosis, that too many people were being written off, and too many people weren’t getting the support they needed.Wes Streeting is the secretary of state for health and social care and Labour MP for Ilford NorthDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading

clusters.title: Wheelchair worry for young disabled people | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Wheelchair worry for young disabled people | Letters: Chris Burgess says his daughter has had to reapply for a wheelchair seven times, in response to an article by Paul Sagar. Plus a letter from Charlie HislopPaul Sagar writes eloquently about his experience of the wheelchair service as a well-educated adult, with some access to funds (‘I wish I could say I kept my cool’: my maddening experience with the NHS wheelchair service, 2 December). My 38-year-old daughter was born with a similar level of spinal injury. A wheelchair that is used all day, every day disintegrates after about five years, so she has had to reapply for one seven times. Imagine trying to attend school while negotiating to obtain this essential equipment.Statistics that support a high level of satisfaction with the wheelchair service do not reflect the experiences of younger disabled people who cannot walk or stand. Disability increases with age, and the typical wheelchair user is an elderly person, often a part-time user who can walk indoors. This may account for the satisfaction with the wheelchair service by older users, who are less dependent on a wheelchair than younger users. Chris BurgessStockport, Greater Manchester Continue reading

clusters.title: Sir Terence English obituary
clusters.neutral_headline: Sir Terence English obituary: Pioneering cardiac surgeon who directed the Papworth hospital heart transplant programmeIn August 1979 the cardiac surgeon Terence English, who has died aged 93, was poised to carry out a heart transplant at Papworth hospital in Cambridgeshire. If it did not go to plan, the operation, as well as being a tragedy for the patient, would end his vision for a Papworth heart transplant programme. Reminiscing at Papworth 40 years later, he said: “I very much had my back to the wall. I had a shot and I was going to take it.”A heart transplant is the only lifeline for people with end-stage heart failure, and being able to carry out such an operation successfully had long been a goal for cardiac surgeons. Christiaan Barnard in South Africa performed the first human-to-human heart transplant in 1967, and between 1968 and 1969 Donald Ross carried out three in the UK, but the longest a patient had survived was 107 days. It was thought to be a false dawn, and in 1973 the UK chief medical officer put a moratorium on the procedure. Continue reading

He was poised to perform a transplant in August 1979.
The first human heart transplant was in 1967.
The UK had a moratorium on transplants in 1973.

Continue reading...

He contrasts the approach with the systematic methods used for children.

clusters.title: NHS braces for ‘unprecedented flu wave’ as hospitalised cases in England rise
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS Braces for Unprecedented Flu Wave as Cases Rise

items.title: NHS braces for ‘unprecedented flu wave’ as hospitalised cases in England rise
items.standfirst: Average of 1,717 flu patients in beds last week, up 56% on a year ago, after ‘unusually early’ start to seasonThe NHS is facing an “unprecedented flu wave”, a senior healthcare leader said, as the number of people with the illness in hospitals across England hit a record high.The statistics, published by NHS England as part of its first weekly snapshot of the performance of hospitals this winter, found that an average of 1,717 flu patients were in beds each day last week – more than 50% higher than last year – including 69 patients whose condition was critical. Continue reading...
items.content: Average of 1,717 flu patients in beds last week, up 56% on a year ago, after ‘unusually early’ start to seasonThe NHS is facing an “unprecedented flu wave”, a senior healthcare leader said, as the number of people with the illness in hospitals across England hit a record high.The statistics, published by NHS England as part of its first weekly snapshot of the performance of hospitals this winter, found that an average of 1,717 flu patients were in beds each day last week – more than 50% higher than last year – including 69 patients whose condition was critical. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS is preparing for an "unprecedented flu wave" this winter.
Hospitalized flu cases in England have reached a record high.
An average of 1,717 flu patients were in beds daily last week.
This figure is over 50% higher than the previous year's average.
Sixty-nine patients were in critical condition due to the flu.

clusters.title: ‘It’s absolute anarchy’: Oxygen therapy chambers have led to horrific deaths. Why are Maha elite raving about them?
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘It’s absolute anarchy’: Oxygen therapy chambers have led to horrific deaths. Why are Maha elite raving about them?

items.title: ‘It’s absolute anarchy’: Oxygen therapy chambers have led to horrific deaths. Why are Maha elite raving about them?
items.standfirst: Touted as a cure for everything from wrinkles to autism, the treatment has been hyped by Robert F Kennedy Jr and various celebrities. Experts say it needs to be regulatedWarning: this article contains distressing contentIt was the kind of cold, damp morning that makes it hard to get out of bed, much less get a child out the door. The sun had not even risen when five-year-old Thomas Cooper and his mother, Annie Cooper, arrived for an appointment on 31 January at the Oxford Center in Troy, a northern suburb of Detroit, Michigan.Thomas was an exuberant child with a button nose and pinchable cheeks – a little kid who loved running fast, playing Minecraft and watching Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, according to a GoFundMe set up by his family. He had just received money in a special red envelope for lunar new year, and he planned to spend it later that day with his little brother. But first, he was going to receive hyperbaric oxygen therapy for his attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and sleep apnea. Continue reading...
items.content: Touted as a cure for everything from wrinkles to autism, the treatment has been hyped by Robert F Kennedy Jr and various celebrities. Experts say it needs to be regulatedWarning: this article contains distressing contentIt was the kind of cold, damp morning that makes it hard to get out of bed, much less get a child out the door. The sun had not even risen when five-year-old Thomas Cooper and his mother, Annie Cooper, arrived for an appointment on 31 January at the Oxford Center in Troy, a northern suburb of Detroit, Michigan.Thomas was an exuberant child with a button nose and pinchable cheeks – a little kid who loved running fast, playing Minecraft and watching Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, according to a GoFundMe set up by his family. He had just received money in a special red envelope for lunar new year, and he planned to spend it later that day with his little brother. But first, he was going to receive hyperbaric oxygen therapy for his attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and sleep apnea. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Oxygen therapy chambers are being touted as a cure for various conditions.
Experts express concerns about the safety and regulation of the treatment.
The article contains a distressing account of a child's death.
The child received hyperbaric oxygen therapy for ADHD and sleep apnea.
The treatment is being promoted by celebrities and others.

clusters.title: Parents and young people: share your concerns about ultra-processed foods (UPFs)
clusters.neutral_headline: Parents and young people: share your concerns about ultra-processed foods (UPFs)

items.title: Parents and young people: share your concerns about ultra-processed foods (UPFs)
items.standfirst: We’re particularly interested in hearing from parents in low- and middle-income countries where the rise in childhood obesity is steepestThis month, the Lancet published the world’s largest review on the health threats of ultra-processed foods (UPFs), showing that they are replacing fresh food on every continent and are exposing millions of people to long-term harm. Globally one in 10 children are considered obese, as junk food overwhelms childhood diets. Previous research has shown how susceptible children are to junk food advertising.Parents and young people, are you concerned about the level of UPFs in your diet? Is it easy and affordable to find fresh food and eat healthily where you live? What changes do you think would help encourage healthy eating habits? We’re particularly interested in hearing from parents in low- and middle-income countries where the rise in childhood obesity is steepest. Continue reading...
items.content: We’re particularly interested in hearing from parents in low- and middle-income countries where the rise in childhood obesity is steepestThis month, the Lancet published the world’s largest review on the health threats of ultra-processed foods (UPFs), showing that they are replacing fresh food on every continent and are exposing millions of people to long-term harm. Globally one in 10 children are considered obese, as junk food overwhelms childhood diets. Previous research has shown how susceptible children are to junk food advertising.Parents and young people, are you concerned about the level of UPFs in your diet? Is it easy and affordable to find fresh food and eat healthily where you live? What changes do you think would help encourage healthy eating habits? We’re particularly interested in hearing from parents in low- and middle-income countries where the rise in childhood obesity is steepest. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Lancet published a review on the health threats of ultra-processed foods.
The review shows UPFs are replacing fresh food globally.
One in ten children worldwide are considered obese.
The article seeks input from parents and young people.
It focuses on concerns about UPFs and healthy eating habits.

clusters.title: New Texas law allows residents to sue those suspected of providing access to abortion pills
clusters.neutral_headline: New Texas law allows residents to sue those suspected of providing access to abortion pills

items.title: New Texas law allows residents to sue those suspected of providing access to abortion pills
items.standfirst: Abortion providers, and even manufacturers, will be liable for penalties over pills mailed into the stateResidents of Texas can now sue people who they suspect of making, distributing or mailing abortion pills in or out of the state, in a first-of-its-kind law that aims to dam the flood of abortion pills into states that ban the procedure.Under the new law, which went into effect on Thursday, abortion providers could face penalties of at least $100,000 if they mail pills into Texas. Manufacturers of abortion pills are also eligible to be sued, although women who take abortion pills are not. Continue reading...
items.content: Abortion providers, and even manufacturers, will be liable for penalties over pills mailed into the stateResidents of Texas can now sue people who they suspect of making, distributing or mailing abortion pills in or out of the state, in a first-of-its-kind law that aims to dam the flood of abortion pills into states that ban the procedure.Under the new law, which went into effect on Thursday, abortion providers could face penalties of at least $100,000 if they mail pills into Texas. Manufacturers of abortion pills are also eligible to be sued, although women who take abortion pills are not. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Texas residents can now sue those suspected of providing abortion pills.
Abortion providers and manufacturers face penalties under the new law.
The law aims to restrict the distribution of abortion pills in Texas.
Penalties for providers could be at least $100,000.
Women who take abortion pills are not subject to lawsuits.

clusters.title: MND took our son at 14 - anyone at any age can get it
clusters.neutral_headline: MND took our son at 14 - anyone at any age can get it

items.title: MND took our son at 14 - anyone at any age can get it
items.standfirst: Kyle Sieniawski, from Pontypridd, died last month, after being diagnosed with motor neurone disease in January.
items.content: Kyle Sieniawski, from Pontypridd, died last month, after being diagnosed with motor neurone disease in January.

ai_summary: Kyle Sieniawski, from Pontypridd, died from motor neurone disease.
He was diagnosed with MND in January and passed away last month.
The article highlights the impact of MND on a young person.
It emphasizes that MND can affect individuals of any age.
The story aims to raise awareness about motor neurone disease.
